Introduction  
Our aim is to ensure that  transferring  between services is a smooth, person centred 
and positive experience for our residents.   
We do this by ,  
• practising person centred generic adult social work within a  single service to 
minimise the need for transfers.  
• operating as part of a ‘cradle to grave’ People directorate service  
• ensuring systems are in place to promote and oversee timely transfers of care 
with internal and external agencies.  
• Ensuring effective communication  with the person, family and between 
professionals, internal and external agencies.  
How we work  
Adult Social Care is a single generic service comprising of Social Workers, 
Occupational Therapists, Strengths -based practitioners,  and a dedicated full -time 
principal Social Worker . We work with adults who have physical disability, learning 
disability, mental health, substance misuse, dementia, including older people and 
those who sleep rough in the City.

adult social care team will discuss individual needs with adults and their family or 
carer to find a suitable care home in a suitable location. We currently have adults in 
care homes across the country to be near friends, family, or just to be in an area of 
preference. We aim to ensure that the adult has the things that are most important 
to them and that their accommodation and experience is as personalised as 
possible. The  allocated social worker will visit to review this within 6 to 8 weeks and 
support with any adjustments to enhance the adult’s experience.

How do I find out more? 
If you live in the City and think 
you may need some care and support, you can contact the Adult Social Care Team on 
020 7332 1224 or adultsduty@cityoflondon.gov.uk 
The City Advice Service can also 
provide advice and information on a range of topics, including housing, welfare benefits, debt, employment and family issues. You can contact them on 
020 7392 2919. Will I have to 
pay for the care and support I need? 
If you’re eligible for care and support from the Adult Social Care Team, you may be asked to contribute something towards the cost. 
To calculate any costs you 
would pay, we will ask you to complete a financial assessment, which will ask about any savings and regular income. This information will help us understand if and how much you can afford to contribute to the cost of your care and support.

Will I need to pay for my care and support? 
All people living in City of London are financially assessed for 
their long-term care and support needs. If you are new to the service, then you will be given a Financial Assessment form which we require all people who are assessed to have long term care needs to complete. If you require assistance completing the form, let us know and this can be provided. 
Most people pay only a small contribution or no charge. 
However, some people’s savings are above the threshold and they will pay the full cost of their care. If this is the case, we would consider you to be a self-funder and you can, if you wish to arrange your care and support independently.

Do you provide unpaid help and support to a parent, partner, child, relative, friend or neighbour who could not manage without your help, due to age, physical or mental health issues, substance misuse or disability?

answer:
In London, social care services are available for adults and children, focusing on providing support for those with physical disabilities, learning disabilities, mental health issues, substance misuse, dementia, and older people, as well as those who are homeless. Eligibility for these services generally depends on assessed needs and may require a financial assessment to determine any contributions towards care costs.

**Adult Social Care Services:**
- **Eligibility:** Services are available to adults with physical disabilities, learning disabilities, mental health issues, substance misuse problems, dementia, and older adults. Support is also available for those who are homeless.
- **Services Provided:** 
  - Home care, rapid response, and reablement services
  - Direct payments for personalized care arrangements
  - Residential and nursing care placements, though these are often outside the City of London due to the lack of local facilities
  - Support for carers, with around 30 carers currently receiving assistance
- **Financial Assessment:** Residents may be required to contribute to the cost of care based on savings and income. A financial assessment will determine this contribution.

**Children’s Social Care Services:**
- **Eligibility:** Services are aimed at children and families in need of support, including those with disabilities.
- **Services Provided:** 
  - Support for looked-after children, including health check-ups and assistance with accessing NHS services
  - Transition support for young people with disabilities moving into adulthood

**Practical Steps and Resources:**
- For more information or to request support, residents can contact the Adult Social Care Team at **020 7332 1224** or email **adultsduty@cityoflondon.gov.uk**.
- The City Advice Service offers additional guidance on housing, welfare benefits, and other social issues, reachable at **020 7392 2919**.

For detailed information on services and eligibility, visit the City of London’s official website: [City of London Community and Children's Services](https://www.cityoflondon.gov.uk/services/children-and-families/about-community-and-childrens-services).
